trans-unit.source: Create and deploy a secure ASP.NET Web Forms app with Membership, OAuth, and SQL Database to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create and deploy a secure ASP.NET Web Forms app with Membership, OAuth, and SQL Database to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to build a secure ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms web app that incorporates a SQL Database and deploy the application to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to build a secure ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms web app that incorporates a SQL Database and deploy the application to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create and deploy a secure ASP.NET Web Forms app with Membership, OAuth, and SQL Database to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create and deploy a secure ASP.NET Web Forms app with Membership, OAuth, and SQL Database to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to build a secure ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms web app that incorporates a SQL Database and deploy the application to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to build a secure ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms web app that incorporates a SQL Database and deploy the application to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For an MVC version of this tutorial, see <link><linkText>Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For an MVC version of this tutorial, see <link><linkText>Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can open an Azure account for free, and if you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK automatically installs Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.
trans-unit.target: You can open an Azure account for free, and if you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK automatically installs Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.

trans-unit.source: You can start developing for Azure for free.
trans-unit.target: You can start developing for Azure for free.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience using Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience using Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: Once completing this tutorial, you'll have a web application up and running in the cloud that uses a cloud database.
trans-unit.target: Once completing this tutorial, you'll have a web application up and running in the cloud that uses a cloud database.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn:
trans-unit.target: You'll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to create an ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms project and publish it to Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: How to create an ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms project and publish it to Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: How to use OAuth and the ASP.NET membership to secure your application.
trans-unit.target: How to use OAuth and the ASP.NET membership to secure your application.

trans-unit.source: How to use a single database for both membership and application data.
trans-unit.target: How to use a single database for both membership and application data.

trans-unit.source: How to use Web Forms Scaffolding to create web pages that allow you to modify data.
trans-unit.target: How to use Web Forms Scaffolding to create web pages that allow you to modify data.

trans-unit.source: How to use the new membership API to add users and roles.
trans-unit.target: How to use the new membership API to add users and roles.

trans-unit.source: How to use a SQL database to store data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: How to use a SQL database to store data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You'll build a simple contact list web application that is built on ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms and uses the Entity Framework for database access.
trans-unit.target: You'll build a simple contact list web application that is built on ASP.NET 4.5 Web Forms and uses the Entity Framework for database access.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows the Web Forms page that allows read and write access to the database:
trans-unit.target: The following image shows the Web Forms page that allows read and write access to the database:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contacts - Edit Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contacts - Edit Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can <html></html>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits<html></html> or <html></html>sign up for a free trial<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can <html></html>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits<html></html> or <html></html>sign up for a free trial<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure before signing up for an account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived ASP.NET starter site in Azure for free.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure before signing up for an account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived ASP.NET starter site in Azure for free.

trans-unit.source: No credit card required, no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit card required, no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Set up the Development Environment
trans-unit.target: Set up the Development Environment

trans-unit.source: To start, set up your development environment by installing the Visual Studio 2013 and the Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: To start, set up your development environment by installing the Visual Studio 2013 and the Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: Install <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>, if you don't already have it installed.
trans-unit.target: Install <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>, if you don't already have it installed.

trans-unit.source: Install <link><linkText>Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>. This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2013 before installing the Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013. Depending on how many of the SDK dependencies you already have on your machine, installing the SDK could take a long time, from several minutes to a half hour or more.
trans-unit.target: Install <link><linkText>Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>. This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2013 before installing the Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013. Depending on how many of the SDK dependencies you already have on your machine, installing the SDK could take a long time, from several minutes to a half hour or more.

trans-unit.source: If you are prompted to run or save the installation executable, click Run.
trans-unit.target: If you are prompted to run or save the installation executable, click Run.

trans-unit.source: In the Web Platform Installer window, click Install and proceed with the installation.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Platform Installer window, click Install and proceed with the installation.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web Platform Installer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web Platform Installer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you already have the SDK installed, there will be 0 items to be installed.
trans-unit.target: If you already have the SDK installed, there will be 0 items to be installed.

trans-unit.source: The number of items to install will be noted at the lower left of the Web Platform Installer window.
trans-unit.target: The number of items to install will be noted at the lower left of the Web Platform Installer window.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have Visual Studio Update 2, download and install **Visual Studio 2013 Update 2** or higher.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have Visual Studio Update 2, download and install **Visual Studio 2013 Update 2** or higher.

trans-unit.source: You must install Visual Studio 2013 Update 2 or higher to use Goggle OAuth 2.0 and to use SSL locally without warnings.
trans-unit.target: You must install Visual Studio 2013 Update 2 or higher to use Goggle OAuth 2.0 and to use SSL locally without warnings.

trans-unit.source: Also, you need Update 2 to use Web Forms Scaffolding.
trans-unit.target: Also, you need Update 2 to use Web Forms Scaffolding.

trans-unit.source: When the installation is complete, you have everything necessary to start developing.
trans-unit.target: When the installation is complete, you have everything necessary to start developing.

trans-unit.source: Set up the Azure Environment
trans-unit.target: Set up the Azure Environment

trans-unit.source: In this section you'll set up the Azure environment by creating an Azure and a SQL database in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this section you'll set up the Azure environment by creating an Azure and a SQL database in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create a Web App and a SQL Database in Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a Web App and a SQL Database in Azure

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial your web app will run in a shared hosting environment, which means it runs on virtual machines (VMs) that are shared with other web apps in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial your web app will run in a shared hosting environment, which means it runs on virtual machines (VMs) that are shared with other web apps in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: A shared hosting environment is a low-cost way to get started in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: A shared hosting environment is a low-cost way to get started in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Later, if your web traffic increases, the application can scale to meet the need by running on dedicated VMs.
trans-unit.target: Later, if your web traffic increases, the application can scale to meet the need by running on dedicated VMs.

trans-unit.source: If you need a more complex architecture, you can migrate to an Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: If you need a more complex architecture, you can migrate to an Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: Cloud services run on dedicated VMs that you can configure according to your needs.
trans-unit.target: Cloud services run on dedicated VMs that you can configure according to your needs.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database is a cloud-based relational database service that is built on SQL Server technologies.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database is a cloud-based relational database service that is built on SQL Server technologies.

trans-unit.source: The tools and applications that work with SQL Server also work with SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The tools and applications that work with SQL Server also work with SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Web Apps in the left tab, and then click New.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Web Apps in the left tab, and then click New.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web Platform Installer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web Platform Installer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Web App, and then click Custom Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Web App, and then click Custom Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Custom Create</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Custom Create</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The New Web App - Custom Create wizard opens.
trans-unit.target: The New Web App - Custom Create wizard opens.

trans-unit.source: In the Create Web App step of the wizard, enter a string in the URL box to use as the unique URL for your application.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Web App step of the wizard, enter a string in the URL box to use as the unique URL for your application.

trans-unit.source: The complete URL will consist of what you enter here plus the suffix that you see next to the text box.
trans-unit.target: The complete URL will consist of what you enter here plus the suffix that you see next to the text box.

trans-unit.source: The illustration shows a URL that is probably taken so you must choose a different URL.
trans-unit.target: The illustration shows a URL that is probably taken so you must choose a different URL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contacts - Create New Web Site</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contacts - Create New Web Site</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Web Hosting Plan drop-down list, choose a region that is closest to your location.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Hosting Plan drop-down list, choose a region that is closest to your location.

trans-unit.source: This setting specifies which data center where your VM will run.
trans-unit.target: This setting specifies which data center where your VM will run.

trans-unit.source: In the Database drop-down list, choose Create a free 20 MB SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In the Database drop-down list, choose Create a free 20 MB SQL database.

trans-unit.source: In the DB Connection String Name box, leave the default value of DefaultConnection.
trans-unit.target: In the DB Connection String Name box, leave the default value of DefaultConnection.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow at the bottom of the box.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow at the bottom of the box.

trans-unit.source: The wizard advances to the Specify database settings step.
trans-unit.target: The wizard advances to the Specify database settings step.

trans-unit.source: In the Name box, enter *ContactDB*.
trans-unit.target: In the Name box, enter *ContactDB*.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Database Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Database Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Server box, select New SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: In the Server box, select New SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, if you previously created a SQL Server database, you can select that SQL Server from the dropdown control.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, if you previously created a SQL Server database, you can select that SQL Server from the dropdown control.

trans-unit.source: Set the Region to the same area you created the web app.
trans-unit.target: Set the Region to the same area you created the web app.

trans-unit.source: Enter an administrator Login Name and Password.
trans-unit.target: Enter an administrator Login Name and Password.

trans-unit.source: If you selected New SQL Database server you aren't entering an existing name and password here, you're entering a new name and password that you're defining now to use later when you access the database.
trans-unit.target: If you selected New SQL Database server you aren't entering an existing name and password here, you're entering a new name and password that you're defining now to use later when you access the database.

trans-unit.source: If you selected a SQL Server you've created previously, you'll be prompted for the password to the previous SQL Server account name you created.
trans-unit.target: If you selected a SQL Server you've created previously, you'll be prompted for the password to the previous SQL Server account name you created.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, you won't check the Advanced box.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you won't check the Advanced box.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark at the bottom right of the box to indicate you're finished.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark at the bottom right of the box to indicate you're finished.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Management Portal returns to the Web Apps page, and the Status column shows that the site is being created.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Management Portal returns to the Web Apps page, and the Status column shows that the site is being created.

trans-unit.source: Shortly after (typically less than a minute), the Status column shows that the site was successfully created.
trans-unit.target: Shortly after (typically less than a minute), the Status column shows that the site was successfully created.

trans-unit.source: In the navigation bar at the left, the number of sites you have in your account appears next to the Web App icon, and the number of databases appears next to the SQL Databases icon.
trans-unit.target: In the navigation bar at the left, the number of sites you have in your account appears next to the Web App icon, and the number of databases appears next to the SQL Databases icon.

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET Web Forms Application
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET Web Forms Application

trans-unit.source: You have created a web app, but there is no content in it yet.
trans-unit.target: You have created a web app, but there is no content in it yet.

trans-unit.source: Your next step is to create the Visual Studio web app that you'll publish to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Your next step is to create the Visual Studio web app that you'll publish to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create the Project
trans-unit.target: Create the Project

trans-unit.source: Select New Project from the File menu in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Select New Project from the File menu in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>File Menu - New Project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>File Menu - New Project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Templates -> Visual C# -> Web templates group on the left.
trans-unit.target: Select the Templates -> Visual C# -> Web templates group on the left.

trans-unit.source: Choose the ASP.NET Web Application template in the center column.
trans-unit.target: Choose the ASP.NET Web Application template in the center column.

trans-unit.source: Name your project ContactManager and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Name your project ContactManager and click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Project Dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Project Dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The name of the project in this tutorial series is ContactManager.
trans-unit.target: The name of the project in this tutorial series is ContactManager.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended that you use this exact project name so that the code provided throughout the tutorial series functions as expected.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended that you use this exact project name so that the code provided throughout the tutorial series functions as expected.

trans-unit.source: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog box, select the Web Forms template.
trans-unit.target: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog box, select the Web Forms template.

trans-unit.source: Uncheck the Host in the cloud check box if it is selected and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Uncheck the Host in the cloud check box if it is selected and click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New ASP.NET Project dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New ASP.NET Project dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Web Forms application will be created.
trans-unit.target: The Web Forms application will be created.

trans-unit.source: Update the Master Page
trans-unit.target: Update the Master Page

trans-unit.source: In ASP.NET Web Forms, master pages allow you to create a consistent layout for the pages in your application.
trans-unit.target: In ASP.NET Web Forms, master pages allow you to create a consistent layout for the pages in your application.

trans-unit.source: A single master page defines the look and feel and standard behavior that you want for all of the pages (or a group of pages) in your application.
trans-unit.target: A single master page defines the look and feel and standard behavior that you want for all of the pages (or a group of pages) in your application.

trans-unit.source: You can then create individual content pages that contain the content you want to display.
trans-unit.target: You can then create individual content pages that contain the content you want to display.

trans-unit.source: When users request the content pages, ASP.NET merges them with the master page to produce output that combines the layout of the master page with the content from the content page.
trans-unit.target: When users request the content pages, ASP.NET merges them with the master page to produce output that combines the layout of the master page with the content from the content page.

trans-unit.source: The new site needs the application name and a link updated.
trans-unit.target: The new site needs the application name and a link updated.

trans-unit.source: The link will point to a page that will display contact details.
trans-unit.target: The link will point to a page that will display contact details.

trans-unit.source: To make these changes you will modify the HTML on the master page.
trans-unit.target: To make these changes you will modify the HTML on the master page.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, find and open the Site.Master page.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, find and open the Site.Master page.

trans-unit.source: If the page is in Design view, switch to Source view.
trans-unit.target: If the page is in Design view, switch to Source view.

trans-unit.source: Update the master page by modifying or adding markup so that the markup for the page appears as follows:
trans-unit.target: Update the master page by modifying or adding markup so that the markup for the page appears as follows:

trans-unit.source: Later in this tutorial you will add Web Forms scaffolding.
trans-unit.target: Later in this tutorial you will add Web Forms scaffolding.

trans-unit.source: Scaffolding will create the page that the above “Contact Demo” link references.
trans-unit.target: Scaffolding will create the page that the above “Contact Demo” link references.

trans-unit.source: Run the Application Locally
trans-unit.target: Run the Application Locally

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Default.aspx page and select Set As Start Page.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Default.aspx page and select Set As Start Page.

trans-unit.source: Next, press CTRL+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Next, press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: The application default page appears in the default browser window.
trans-unit.target: The application default page appears in the default browser window.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contacts - Create New Web Site</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contacts - Create New Web Site</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This is all you need to do for now to create the application that you'll deploy to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This is all you need to do for now to create the application that you'll deploy to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Later, you'll add database functionality, as well as the necessary pages to display and edit contact data.
trans-unit.target: Later, you'll add database functionality, as well as the necessary pages to display and edit contact data.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the Application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the Application to Azure

trans-unit.source: Now that you have created and ran your application locally, it is time to deploy the application to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have created and ran your application locally, it is time to deploy the application to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Publish</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Publish</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Publish Web dialog box is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Publish Web dialog box is displayed.

trans-unit.source: In the Profile tab of the Publish Web dialog box, click Azure Web App.
trans-unit.target: In the Profile tab of the Publish Web dialog box, click Azure Web App.

trans-unit.source: If you are not already signed in, click the Sign In button in the Select Existing Web App dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you are not already signed in, click the Sign In button in the Select Existing Web App dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Once you've finished signing in, select the web app you created in the first part of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Once you've finished signing in, select the web app you created in the first part of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to continue.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to continue.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Existing Web Site dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Existing Web Site dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will download your publishing settings.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will download your publishing settings.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish Web dialog box, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish Web dialog box, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You will see the overall publishing status in the Web Publish Activity window within Visual Studio:
trans-unit.target: You will see the overall publishing status in the Web Publish Activity window within Visual Studio:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web Publishing Activity</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web Publishing Activity</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The application you created is now running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The application you created is now running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The next time you deploy the application from Visual Studio, only the changed (or new) files will be deployed.
trans-unit.target: The next time you deploy the application from Visual Studio, only the changed (or new) files will be deployed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>App in Browser</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>App in Browser</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you run into an error while publishing to an already established web app, you can clear the location before adding your new files.
trans-unit.target: If you run into an error while publishing to an already established web app, you can clear the location before adding your new files.

trans-unit.source: Publish your application again, however in the Publish Web dialog box, select the Settings tab.
trans-unit.target: Publish your application again, however in the Publish Web dialog box, select the Settings tab.

trans-unit.source: Then, set the configuration to Debug and select the option to Remove additional files at destination.
trans-unit.target: Then, set the configuration to Debug and select the option to Remove additional files at destination.

trans-unit.source: Select Publish to deploy your application again.
trans-unit.target: Select Publish to deploy your application again.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add a Database to the Application
trans-unit.target: Add a Database to the Application

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll update the Web Forms application to add the capability to display and update contacts, as well as store the data in the default database.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll update the Web Forms application to add the capability to display and update contacts, as well as store the data in the default database.

trans-unit.source: When you created the Web Forms project, the database was also created by default.
trans-unit.target: When you created the Web Forms project, the database was also created by default.

trans-unit.source: The application will use Entity Framework to access the database and to read and update data in the database.
trans-unit.target: The application will use Entity Framework to access the database and to read and update data in the database.

trans-unit.source: Add a Data Model Class
trans-unit.target: Add a Data Model Class

trans-unit.source: You begin by creating a simple data model using code.
trans-unit.target: You begin by creating a simple data model using code.

trans-unit.source: This data model will be contained in a class called Contacts.
trans-unit.target: This data model will be contained in a class called Contacts.

trans-unit.source: The Contacts class name was chosen to avoid a class name conflict with the Contact class contained in the Contact.aspx.cs file created by the Web Forms template.
trans-unit.target: The Contacts class name was chosen to avoid a class name conflict with the Contact class contained in the Contact.aspx.cs file created by the Web Forms template.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder and then select Add -> Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder and then select Add -> Class.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Class</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Class</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Add New Item dialog box is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Add New Item dialog box is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Name this new class Contacts.cs.
trans-unit.target: Name this new class Contacts.cs.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add New Item dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add New Item dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace the default code with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Replace the default code with the following code:

trans-unit.source: The Contacts class defines the data that you will store for each contact, plus a primary key (ContactID) that is needed by the database.
trans-unit.target: The Contacts class defines the data that you will store for each contact, plus a primary key (ContactID) that is needed by the database.

trans-unit.source: The Contacts class represents the contact data that will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Contacts class represents the contact data that will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Each instance of a Contacts object will correspond to a row within a relational database table, and each property of the Contacts class will map to a column in the relational database table.
trans-unit.target: Each instance of a Contacts object will correspond to a row within a relational database table, and each property of the Contacts class will map to a column in the relational database table.

trans-unit.source: Later in this tutorial, you'll review the contact data contained in the database.
trans-unit.target: Later in this tutorial, you'll review the contact data contained in the database.

trans-unit.source: Web Forms Scaffolding
trans-unit.target: Web Forms Scaffolding

trans-unit.source: You've created the Contacts model class above.
trans-unit.target: You've created the Contacts model class above.

trans-unit.source: Now, you can use the Web Forms Scaffolder to generate List, Insert, Edit and Delete pages that are used when working with this data.
trans-unit.target: Now, you can use the Web Forms Scaffolder to generate List, Insert, Edit and Delete pages that are used when working with this data.

trans-unit.source: The Web Forms Scaffolder uses Entity Framework, Bootstrap, and Dynamic Data.
trans-unit.target: The Web Forms Scaffolder uses Entity Framework, Bootstrap, and Dynamic Data.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Web Forms Scaffolder is installed as an extension to your project as part of the project template when using Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Web Forms Scaffolder is installed as an extension to your project as part of the project template when using Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: The following steps will allow you to use the Web Forms Scaffolder.
trans-unit.target: The following steps will allow you to use the Web Forms Scaffolder.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, from the menu bar select Tools -> Extensions and Updates.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, from the menu bar select Tools -> Extensions and Updates.

trans-unit.source: The Extensions and Updates dialog box is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Extensions and Updates dialog box is displayed.

trans-unit.source: From the left pane of the dialog box, select Online -> Visual Studio Gallery -> Tools -> Scaffolding.
trans-unit.target: From the left pane of the dialog box, select Online -> Visual Studio Gallery -> Tools -> Scaffolding.

trans-unit.source: If you don't see 'Web Forms Scaffolding' in the list, enter 'Web Forms Scaffolding' in the search box on the right of the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you don't see 'Web Forms Scaffolding' in the list, enter 'Web Forms Scaffolding' in the search box on the right of the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: If the Web Forms Scaffolder is not already installed, select Download to download and install 'Web Forms Scaffolding'.
trans-unit.target: If the Web Forms Scaffolder is not already installed, select Download to download and install 'Web Forms Scaffolding'.

trans-unit.source: Restart Visual Studio if needed.
trans-unit.target: Restart Visual Studio if needed.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to save your changes to the project when requested.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to save your changes to the project when requested.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Extensions and Updates dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Extensions and Updates dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).
trans-unit.target: Build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).

trans-unit.source: You must build the project before using the scaffolding mechanism.
trans-unit.target: You must build the project before using the scaffolding mechanism.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and then select Add -> New Scaffolded Item.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and then select Add -> New Scaffolded Item.

trans-unit.source: The Add Scaffold dialog box is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Add Scaffold dialog box is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Select Web Forms from the left pane and select Web Forms Pages using Entity Framework from the center pane.
trans-unit.target: Select Web Forms from the left pane and select Web Forms Pages using Entity Framework from the center pane.

trans-unit.source: Then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Then click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Scaffold dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Scaffold dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Add Web Forms Pages dialog box is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Add Web Forms Pages dialog box is displayed.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Web Forms Pages dialog box, set the Model class to Contacts (ContactManager.Models).
trans-unit.target: In the Add Web Forms Pages dialog box, set the Model class to Contacts (ContactManager.Models).

trans-unit.source: Set the Data context class to ApplicationDbContext (ContactManager.Models).
trans-unit.target: Set the Data context class to ApplicationDbContext (ContactManager.Models).

trans-unit.source: Then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Then click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Web Forms Pages dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Web Forms Pages dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Web Forms Scaffolder adds a new folder that contains Default.aspx, Delete.aspx, Edit.aspx, and Insert.aspx pages.
trans-unit.target: The Web Forms Scaffolder adds a new folder that contains Default.aspx, Delete.aspx, Edit.aspx, and Insert.aspx pages.

trans-unit.source: The Web Forms Scaffolder also creates a DynamicData folder that contains an EntityTemplates folder and a FieldTemplates folder.
trans-unit.target: The Web Forms Scaffolder also creates a DynamicData folder that contains an EntityTemplates folder and a FieldTemplates folder.

trans-unit.source: The ApplicationDbContext will be used for both the membership database and the contact data.
trans-unit.target: The ApplicationDbContext will be used for both the membership database and the contact data.

trans-unit.source: Configure the Application to use the Data Model
trans-unit.target: Configure the Application to use the Data Model

trans-unit.source: The next task is to enable the Code First Migrations feature in order to create the database based on the data model you created.
trans-unit.target: The next task is to enable the Code First Migrations feature in order to create the database based on the data model you created.

trans-unit.source: Also, you will add sample data and a data initializer.
trans-unit.target: Also, you will add sample data and a data initializer.

trans-unit.source: In the Tools menu, select NuGet Package Manager and then Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: In the Tools menu, select NuGet Package Manager and then Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Web Forms Pages dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Web Forms Pages dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The enable-migrations command creates a Migrations folder, and it puts in that folder a Configuration.cs file that you can edit to seed the database and configure data migrations.
trans-unit.target: The enable-migrations command creates a Migrations folder, and it puts in that folder a Configuration.cs file that you can edit to seed the database and configure data migrations.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The add-migration Initial command generates a file named Initial in the Migrations folder that creates the database. The first parameter ( Initial ) is arbitrary and is used to create the name of the file. You can see the new class files in Solution Explorer. In the Initial class, the Up method creates the Contact table, and the Down method (used when you want to return to the previous state) drops it.
trans-unit.target: The add-migration Initial command generates a file named Initial in the Migrations folder that creates the database. The first parameter ( Initial ) is arbitrary and is used to create the name of the file. You can see the new class files in Solution Explorer. In the Initial class, the Up method creates the Contact table, and the Down method (used when you want to return to the previous state) drops it.

trans-unit.source: Open the Migrations\Configuration.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Open the Migrations\Configuration.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Add the following namespace:
trans-unit.target: Add the following namespace:

trans-unit.source: Replace the Seed method with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Replace the Seed method with the following code:

trans-unit.source: This code initializes (seeds) the database with the contact information.
trans-unit.target: This code initializes (seeds) the database with the contact information.

trans-unit.source: For more information on seeding the database, see <link><linkText>Seeding and Debugging Entity Framework (EF) DBs</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on seeding the database, see <link><linkText>Seeding and Debugging Entity Framework (EF) DBs</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console enter the command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console enter the command:

trans-unit.source: The update-database runs the first migration which creates the database.
trans-unit.target: The update-database runs the first migration which creates the database.

trans-unit.source: By default, the database is created as a SQL Server Express LocalDB database.
trans-unit.target: By default, the database is created as a SQL Server Express LocalDB database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Package Manager Console</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Package Manager Console</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Run the Application Locally and Display the Data
trans-unit.target: Run the Application Locally and Display the Data

trans-unit.source: Run the application now to see how you can view the contacts.
trans-unit.target: Run the application now to see how you can view the contacts.

trans-unit.source: First, build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).
trans-unit.target: First, build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).

trans-unit.source: Press Ctrl+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press Ctrl+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: The browser will open and show the Default.aspx page.
trans-unit.target: The browser will open and show the Default.aspx page.

trans-unit.source: Select the Contact Demo link at the top of the page to display the Contact List page.
trans-unit.target: Select the Contact Demo link at the top of the page to display the Contact List page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contacts List Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contacts List Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enable SSL for the Project
trans-unit.target: Enable SSL for the Project

trans-unit.source: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) is a protocol defined to allow Web servers and Web clients to communicate more securely through the use of encryption.
trans-unit.target: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) is a protocol defined to allow Web servers and Web clients to communicate more securely through the use of encryption.

trans-unit.source: When SSL is not used, data sent between the client and server is open to packet sniffing by anyone with physical access to the network.
trans-unit.target: When SSL is not used, data sent between the client and server is open to packet sniffing by anyone with physical access to the network.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, several common authentication schemes are not secure over plain HTTP.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, several common authentication schemes are not secure over plain HTTP.

trans-unit.source: In particular, Basic authentication and forms authentication send unencrypted credentials.
trans-unit.target: In particular, Basic authentication and forms authentication send unencrypted credentials.

trans-unit.source: To be secure, these authentication schemes must use SSL.
trans-unit.target: To be secure, these authentication schemes must use SSL.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, click the ContactManager project, then press F4 to display the Properties window.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, click the ContactManager project, then press F4 to display the Properties window.

trans-unit.source: Change SSL Enabled to true.
trans-unit.target: Change SSL Enabled to true.

trans-unit.source: Copy the SSL URL so you can use it later.
trans-unit.target: Copy the SSL URL so you can use it later.

trans-unit.source: The SSL URL will be https://localhost:44300/ unless you've previously created SSL web app (as shown below).
trans-unit.target: The SSL URL will be https://localhost:44300/ unless you've previously created SSL web app (as shown below).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project Properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project Properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click the Contact Manager project and click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click the Contact Manager project and click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the left tab, click Web.
trans-unit.target: In the left tab, click Web.

trans-unit.source: Change the Project Url to use the SSL URL that you saved earlier.
trans-unit.target: Change the Project Url to use the SSL URL that you saved earlier.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project Web Properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project Web Properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the page by pressing CTRL+S.
trans-unit.target: Save the page by pressing CTRL+S.

trans-unit.source: Press Ctrl+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press Ctrl+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will display an option to allow you to avoid SSL warnings.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will display an option to allow you to avoid SSL warnings.

trans-unit.source: Click Yes to trust the IIS Express SSL certificate and continue.
trans-unit.target: Click Yes to trust the IIS Express SSL certificate and continue.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>IIS Express SSL certificate details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>IIS Express SSL certificate details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A Security Warning is displayed.
trans-unit.target: A Security Warning is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Click Yes to install the certificate to your localhost.
trans-unit.target: Click Yes to install the certificate to your localhost.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Security Warning dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Security Warning dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The browser window will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: The browser window will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: You can easily test your Web application locally using SSL.
trans-unit.target: You can easily test your Web application locally using SSL.

trans-unit.source: Add an OAuth 2.0 Provider
trans-unit.target: Add an OAuth 2.0 Provider

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET Web Forms provides enhanced options for membership and authentication.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET Web Forms provides enhanced options for membership and authentication.

trans-unit.source: These enhancements include OAuth.
trans-unit.target: These enhancements include OAuth.

trans-unit.source: OAuth is an open protocol that allows secure authorization in a simple and standard method from web, mobile, and desktop applications.
trans-unit.target: OAuth is an open protocol that allows secure authorization in a simple and standard method from web, mobile, and desktop applications.

trans-unit.source: The ASP.NET MVC internet template uses OAuth to expose Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft as authentication providers.
trans-unit.target: The ASP.NET MVC internet template uses OAuth to expose Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft as authentication providers.

trans-unit.source: Although this tutorial uses only Google as the authentication provider, you can easily modify the code to use any of the providers.
trans-unit.target: Although this tutorial uses only Google as the authentication provider, you can easily modify the code to use any of the providers.

trans-unit.source: The steps to implement other providers are very similar to the steps you will see in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The steps to implement other providers are very similar to the steps you will see in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In addition to authentication, the tutorial will also use roles to implement authorization.
trans-unit.target: In addition to authentication, the tutorial will also use roles to implement authorization.

trans-unit.source: Only those users you add to the canEdit role will be able to change data (create, edit, or delete contacts).
trans-unit.target: Only those users you add to the canEdit role will be able to change data (create, edit, or delete contacts).

trans-unit.source: The following steps will allow you to add a Google authentication provider.
trans-unit.target: The following steps will allow you to add a Google authentication provider.

trans-unit.source: Open the App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Open the App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Remove the comment characters from the app.UseGoogleAuthentication() method so that the method appears as follows:
trans-unit.target: Remove the comment characters from the app.UseGoogleAuthentication() method so that the method appears as follows:

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the <link><linkText>Google Developers Console</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the <link><linkText>Google Developers Console</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You will also need to sign-in with your Google developer email account (gmail.com).
trans-unit.target: You will also need to sign-in with your Google developer email account (gmail.com).

trans-unit.source: If you do not have a Google account, select the Create an account link.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have a Google account, select the Create an account link.

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll see the Google Developers Console.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll see the Google Developers Console.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Google Developers Console</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Google Developers Console</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Create Project button and enter a project name and ID (you can use the default values).
trans-unit.target: Click the Create Project button and enter a project name and ID (you can use the default values).

trans-unit.source: Then, click the agreement checkbox and the Create button.
trans-unit.target: Then, click the agreement checkbox and the Create button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Google - New Project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Google - New Project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In a few seconds the new project will be created and your browser will display the new projects page.
trans-unit.target: In a few seconds the new project will be created and your browser will display the new projects page.

trans-unit.source: In the left tab, click APIs & auth, and then click Credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the left tab, click APIs & auth, and then click Credentials.

trans-unit.source: Click the Create New Client ID under OAuth.
trans-unit.target: Click the Create New Client ID under OAuth.

trans-unit.source: The Create Client ID dialog will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Create Client ID dialog will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Google - Create Client ID</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Google - Create Client ID</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create Client ID dialog, keep the default Web application for the application type.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Client ID dialog, keep the default Web application for the application type.

trans-unit.source: Set the Authorized JavaScript Origins to the SSL URL you used earlier in this tutorial (https://localhost:44300/ unless you've created other SSL projects).
trans-unit.target: Set the Authorized JavaScript Origins to the SSL URL you used earlier in this tutorial (https://localhost:44300/ unless you've created other SSL projects).

trans-unit.source: This URL is the origin for your application.
trans-unit.target: This URL is the origin for your application.

trans-unit.source: For this sample, you will only enter the localhost test URL.
trans-unit.target: For this sample, you will only enter the localhost test URL.

trans-unit.source: However, you can enter multiple URL to account for localhost and production.
trans-unit.target: However, you can enter multiple URL to account for localhost and production.

trans-unit.source: Set the Authorized Redirect URI to the following:
trans-unit.target: Set the Authorized Redirect URI to the following:

trans-unit.source: This value is the URI that ASP.NET OAuth users to communicate with the google OAuth server.
trans-unit.target: This value is the URI that ASP.NET OAuth users to communicate with the google OAuth server.

trans-unit.source: Remember to the SSL URL you used above (https://localhost:44300/ unless you've created other SSL projects).
trans-unit.target: Remember to the SSL URL you used above (https://localhost:44300/ unless you've created other SSL projects).

trans-unit.source: Click the Create Client ID button.
trans-unit.target: Click the Create Client ID button.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, update the UseGoogleAuthentication method of the Startup.Auth.cs page by copying and pasting the AppId and App Secret into the method.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, update the UseGoogleAuthentication method of the Startup.Auth.cs page by copying and pasting the AppId and App Secret into the method.

trans-unit.source: The AppId and App Secret values shown below are samples and will not work.
trans-unit.target: The AppId and App Secret values shown below are samples and will not work.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to build and run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to build and run the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the Log in link.
trans-unit.target: Click the Log in link.

trans-unit.source: Under Use another service to log in, click Google.
trans-unit.target: Under Use another service to log in, click Google.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Log in</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Log in</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you need to enter your credentials, you will be redirected to the google site where you will enter your credentials.
trans-unit.target: If you need to enter your credentials, you will be redirected to the google site where you will enter your credentials.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Google - Sign in</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Google - Sign in</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After you enter your credentials, you will be prompted to give permissions to the web application you just created:
trans-unit.target: After you enter your credentials, you will be prompted to give permissions to the web application you just created:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project Default Service Account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project Default Service Account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Accept.
trans-unit.target: Click Accept.

trans-unit.source: You will now be redirected back to the Register page of the ContactManager application where you can register your Google account.
trans-unit.target: You will now be redirected back to the Register page of the ContactManager application where you can register your Google account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Register with your Google Account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Register with your Google Account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You have the option of changing the local email registration name used for your Gmail account, but you generally want to keep the default email alias (that is, the one you used for authentication).
trans-unit.target: You have the option of changing the local email registration name used for your Gmail account, but you generally want to keep the default email alias (that is, the one you used for authentication).

trans-unit.source: Click Log in.
trans-unit.target: Click Log in.

trans-unit.source: Use the Membership API to Restrict Access
trans-unit.target: Use the Membership API to Restrict Access

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET Identity is the membership system used for authentication when building an ASP.NET web application.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET Identity is the membership system used for authentication when building an ASP.NET web application.

trans-unit.source: It makes it easy to integrate user-specific profile data with application data.
trans-unit.target: It makes it easy to integrate user-specific profile data with application data.

trans-unit.source: Also, ASP.NET Identity allows you to choose the persistence model for user profiles in your application.
trans-unit.target: Also, ASP.NET Identity allows you to choose the persistence model for user profiles in your application.

trans-unit.source: You can store the data in a SQL Server database or another data store, including NoSQL data stores such as Azure Storage Tables.
trans-unit.target: You can store the data in a SQL Server database or another data store, including NoSQL data stores such as Azure Storage Tables.

trans-unit.source: By using the default ASP.NET Web Forms template, you have built-in membership functionality that you can immediately use when the application runs.
trans-unit.target: By using the default ASP.NET Web Forms template, you have built-in membership functionality that you can immediately use when the application runs.

trans-unit.source: You will use ASP.NET Identity to add an administrator role and assign a user to that role.
trans-unit.target: You will use ASP.NET Identity to add an administrator role and assign a user to that role.

trans-unit.source: Then, you will learn how to restrict access to the administration folder and the pages in that folder that are used to modify the contact data.
trans-unit.target: Then, you will learn how to restrict access to the administration folder and the pages in that folder that are used to modify the contact data.

trans-unit.source: Add an Administrator
trans-unit.target: Add an Administrator

trans-unit.source: Using ASP.NET Identity, you can add an administrator role and assign a user to that role using code.
trans-unit.target: Using ASP.NET Identity, you can add an administrator role and assign a user to that role using code.

trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the Configuration.cs file in the Migrations folder.

trans-unit.target: Add the following using statements within the ContactManger.Migrations namespace:

trans-unit.target: Add the following AddUserAndRole method to the Configuration class after the Seed method:

trans-unit.target: Add a call to the AddUserAndRole method from within the beginning of the Seed method.

trans-unit.source: Note that only the beginning of the Seed method is being shown.
trans-unit.target: Note that only the beginning of the Seed method is being shown.

trans-unit.source: After saving all your changes, in the Package Manager Console run the following command:
trans-unit.target: After saving all your changes, in the Package Manager Console run the following command:

trans-unit.source: This code creates a new role called canEdit and creates a new local user with the email of canEditUser@wideworldimporters.com.
trans-unit.target: This code creates a new role called canEdit and creates a new local user with the email of canEditUser@wideworldimporters.com.

trans-unit.source: Then, the code adds canEditUser@wideworldimporters.com to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: Then, the code adds canEditUser@wideworldimporters.com to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>ASP.NET Identity</linkText><title></title></link> resource page.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>ASP.NET Identity</linkText><title></title></link> resource page.

trans-unit.source: Restrict Access to the Administration Folder
trans-unit.target: Restrict Access to the Administration Folder

trans-unit.source: The ContactManager sample application allows both anonymous users and logged-in users to view contacts.
trans-unit.target: The ContactManager sample application allows both anonymous users and logged-in users to view contacts.

trans-unit.source: However, after you complete this section, the logged-in users that are assigned to the "canEdit" role will be the only users able to modify the contacts.
trans-unit.target: However, after you complete this section, the logged-in users that are assigned to the "canEdit" role will be the only users able to modify the contacts.

trans-unit.source: You will create a folder named Admin where only users that are assigned to the "canEdit" role can access.
trans-unit.target: You will create a folder named Admin where only users that are assigned to the "canEdit" role can access.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, add a sub-folder to the Contacts folder and name the new sub-folder Admin.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, add a sub-folder to the Contacts folder and name the new sub-folder Admin.

trans-unit.source: Move the following files from the Contacts folder to the Contacts/Admin folder:
trans-unit.target: Move the following files from the Contacts folder to the Contacts/Admin folder:

trans-unit.target: Delete.aspx *and Delete.aspx.cs*

trans-unit.source: Edit.aspx *and Edit.aspx.cs*
trans-unit.target: Edit.aspx *and Edit.aspx.cs*

trans-unit.source: Insert.aspx *and Insert.aspx.cs*
trans-unit.target: Insert.aspx *and Insert.aspx.cs*

trans-unit.target: Update the link references in Contacts/Default.aspx by adding "Admin/" before the pages references that link to Insert.aspx, Edit.aspx, and Delete.aspx as shown below:

trans-unit.target: Update the six references of the Response.Redirect("Default.aspx") code to Response.Redirect("~/Contacts/Default.aspx") for the following three files:

trans-unit.target: Delete.aspx.cs

trans-unit.target: Edit.aspx.cs

trans-unit.source: Insert.aspx.cs
trans-unit.target: Insert.aspx.cs

trans-unit.source: Now the links will all work correctly when you display and update the contact data.
trans-unit.target: Now the links will all work correctly when you display and update the contact data.

trans-unit.source: To restrict access to the Admin folder, from the Solution Explorer right-click the Admin folder and select Add New Item.
trans-unit.target: To restrict access to the Admin folder, from the Solution Explorer right-click the Admin folder and select Add New Item.

trans-unit.source: From the list of Visual C# Web templates, select Web Configuration File from the middle list, accept the default name of Web.config, and then select Add.
trans-unit.target: From the list of Visual C# Web templates, select Web Configuration File from the middle list, accept the default name of Web.config, and then select Add.

trans-unit.source: Replace the existing XML content in the Web.config file with the following:
trans-unit.target: Replace the existing XML content in the Web.config file with the following:

trans-unit.source: Save the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: Save the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: The Web.config file specifies that only users assigned to the "canEdit" role can access the pages contained in the Admin folder.
trans-unit.target: The Web.config file specifies that only users assigned to the "canEdit" role can access the pages contained in the Admin folder.

trans-unit.source: When a user that is not part of the "canEdit" role attempts to modify the data, they will be redirected to the Log in page.
trans-unit.target: When a user that is not part of the "canEdit" role attempts to modify the data, they will be redirected to the Log in page.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the Application with the Database to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the Application with the Database to Azure

trans-unit.source: Now that the web application is complete, you can publish it to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that the web application is complete, you can publish it to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Publish the Application
trans-unit.target: Publish the Application

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish menu option</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish menu option</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Publish Web dialog box is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Publish Web dialog box is displayed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Profile tab, select Azure Web App as the publish target if it is not already selected.
trans-unit.target: From the Profile tab, select Azure Web App as the publish target if it is not already selected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Sign In if you are not already signed in.
trans-unit.target: Click Sign In if you are not already signed in.

trans-unit.source: Select the existing web app that you created earlier in this tutorial from the Existing Web Apps dropdown box and click the OK button.
trans-unit.target: Select the existing web app that you created earlier in this tutorial from the Existing Web Apps dropdown box and click the OK button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Existing Web Site dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Existing Web Site dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you are asked to save changes make to the profile, select Yes.
trans-unit.target: If you are asked to save changes make to the profile, select Yes.

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings tab.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Existing Web Site dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Existing Web Site dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Set the Configuration dropdown box to Debug.
trans-unit.target: Set the Configuration dropdown box to Debug.

trans-unit.source: Click the down arrow icon next to ApplicationDbContext and set it to ContactDB.
trans-unit.target: Click the down arrow icon next to ApplicationDbContext and set it to ContactDB.

trans-unit.source: Check the Execute Code First Migrations checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Check the Execute Code First Migrations checkbox.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you should select this checkbox only the first time you publish the application.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you should select this checkbox only the first time you publish the application.

trans-unit.source: This way, the Seed method in the Configuration.cs file will only be called once.
trans-unit.target: This way, the Seed method in the Configuration.cs file will only be called once.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Your application will be published to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Your application will be published to Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you closed and re-opened Visual Studio after you created the publish profile, you might not see the connection string in the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: If you closed and re-opened Visual Studio after you created the publish profile, you might not see the connection string in the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: In that case, instead of editing the publish profile that you created earlier, create a new one the same way you did earlier, and then follow these steps on the Settings tab.)
trans-unit.target: In that case, instead of editing the publish profile that you created earlier, create a new one the same way you did earlier, and then follow these steps on the Settings tab.)

trans-unit.source: Review the Application in Azure
trans-unit.target: Review the Application in Azure

trans-unit.source: In the browser, click the Contact Demo link.
trans-unit.target: In the browser, click the Contact Demo link.

trans-unit.source: The Contacts List is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Contacts List is displayed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contacts listed in Browser</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contacts listed in Browser</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Create new on the Contacts List page.
trans-unit.target: Select Create new on the Contacts List page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contacts listed in Browser</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contacts listed in Browser</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You are redirected to the Login page because you have not logged in with an account that can modify contacts.
trans-unit.target: You are redirected to the Login page because you have not logged in with an account that can modify contacts.

trans-unit.source: After you enter the below email and password, click the Log in button.
trans-unit.target: After you enter the below email and password, click the Log in button.

trans-unit.source: Email: canEditUser@wideworldimporters.com
trans-unit.target: Email: canEditUser@wideworldimporters.com

trans-unit.source: Password: Pa$$word1
trans-unit.target: Password: Pa$$word1

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Log in Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Log in Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter new data for each field and then press the Insert button.
trans-unit.target: Enter new data for each field and then press the Insert button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add New Contact Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add New Contact Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The EditContactList.aspx page is displayed with the new record.
trans-unit.target: The EditContactList.aspx page is displayed with the new record.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add New Contact Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add New Contact Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Log off link.
trans-unit.target: Select the Log off link.

trans-unit.source: Stop the Application
trans-unit.target: Stop the Application

trans-unit.source: In order to prevent other people from registering and using your sample application, you will stop the web app.
trans-unit.target: In order to prevent other people from registering and using your sample application, you will stop the web app.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio from the View Menu, select Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio from the View Menu, select Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, navigate to Web App.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, navigate to Web App.

trans-unit.source: Right click on each web app instance and select Stop Web App.
trans-unit.target: Right click on each web app instance and select Stop Web App.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Stop Web Site menu item</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Stop Web Site menu item</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, from the Microsoft Azure management portal, you can select the web app, then click the stop icon at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, from the Microsoft Azure management portal, you can select the web app, then click the stop icon at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add New Contact Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add New Contact Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Review the Database
trans-unit.target: Review the Database

trans-unit.source: It is important to know how to view and modify the database directly.
trans-unit.target: It is important to know how to view and modify the database directly.

trans-unit.source: Knowing how to work directly with the database allows you to confirm data in the database and also understand how the data is stored in each table.
trans-unit.target: Knowing how to work directly with the database allows you to confirm data in the database and also understand how the data is stored in each table.

trans-unit.source: Examine the SQL Azure DB
trans-unit.target: Examine the SQL Azure DB

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open Server Explorer and navigate to ContactDB.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open Server Explorer and navigate to ContactDB.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on ContactDB and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on ContactDB and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open in SQL Server Object Explorer menu item</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open in SQL Server Object Explorer menu item</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If the Add Firewall Rule dialog box is displayed, select Add Firewall Rule.
trans-unit.target: If the Add Firewall Rule dialog box is displayed, select Add Firewall Rule.

trans-unit.source: If you can't expand SQL Databases and can't see ContactDB from Visual Studio, you can follow the instructions to open a firewall port or a range of ports.
trans-unit.target: If you can't expand SQL Databases and can't see ContactDB from Visual Studio, you can follow the instructions to open a firewall port or a range of ports.

trans-unit.source: To do this, follow the instructions under Set up Azure firewall rules near the end of the MVC tutorial.
trans-unit.target: To do this, follow the instructions under Set up Azure firewall rules near the end of the MVC tutorial.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative, you can also review the data of the local database by building, running, and adding data to the application locally (CTRL+F5 from Visual Studio).
trans-unit.target: As an alternative, you can also review the data of the local database by building, running, and adding data to the application locally (CTRL+F5 from Visual Studio).

trans-unit.source: If the Connect to Server dialog box is displayed, enter the password you created at the beginning of this tutorial and press the Connect button.
trans-unit.target: If the Connect to Server dialog box is displayed, enter the password you created at the beginning of this tutorial and press the Connect button.

trans-unit.source: If you don't recall the password, you can find it in your local project file.
trans-unit.target: If you don't recall the password, you can find it in your local project file.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, expand the Properties folder and then expand the PublishProfiles folder.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, expand the Properties folder and then expand the PublishProfiles folder.

trans-unit.source: Open the contactmanager.pubxml file (your file may be named differently).
trans-unit.target: Open the contactmanager.pubxml file (your file may be named differently).

trans-unit.source: Search the file for your publishing password.
trans-unit.target: Search the file for your publishing password.

trans-unit.source: Expand the contactDB database and then expand Tables.
trans-unit.target: Expand the contactDB database and then expand Tables.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the dbo.AspNetUsers table and select View Data.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the dbo.AspNetUsers table and select View Data.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View Data menu item</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View Data menu item</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can view the data associated with the canEditUser@contoso.com user.
trans-unit.target: You can view the data associated with the canEditUser@contoso.com user.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ContactManager window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ContactManager window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add a User to the Admin Role by Editing the Database
trans-unit.target: Add a User to the Admin Role by Editing the Database

trans-unit.source: Earlier in the tutorial you used code to add users to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: Earlier in the tutorial you used code to add users to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: An alternative method is to directly manipulate the data in the membership tables.
trans-unit.target: An alternative method is to directly manipulate the data in the membership tables.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show how to use this alternate method to add a user to a role.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show how to use this alternate method to add a user to a role.

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Object Explorer, right click on dbo.AspNetUserRoles and select View Data.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Object Explorer, right click on dbo.AspNetUserRoles and select View Data.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>AspNetUserRoles data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>AspNetUserRoles data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Copy the RoleId and paste it into the empty (new) row.
trans-unit.target: Copy the RoleId and paste it into the empty (new) row.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>AspNetUserRoles data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>AspNetUserRoles data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the dbo.AspNetUsers table, find the user you want to put in the role, and copy the user's Id.
trans-unit.target: In the dbo.AspNetUsers table, find the user you want to put in the role, and copy the user's Id.

trans-unit.source: Paste the copied Id into the UserId field of the new row in the AspNetUserRoles table.
trans-unit.target: Paste the copied Id into the UserId field of the new row in the AspNetUserRoles table.

trans-unit.source: We are working on a tool that will make managing users and roles much easier.
trans-unit.target: We are working on a tool that will make managing users and roles much easier.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For more information about ASP.NET Web Forms, see <link><linkText>Learn About ASP.NET Web Forms</linkText><title></title></link> on the ASP.NET web app and <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Tutorials and Guides</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about ASP.NET Web Forms, see <link><linkText>Learn About ASP.NET Web Forms</linkText><title></title></link> on the ASP.NET web app and <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Tutorials and Guides</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.target: This tutorial was based on the MVC tutorial <link><linkText>Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> written by Rick Anderson (Twitter <link><linkText>@RickAndMSFT</linkText><title></title></link> with assistance from Tom Dykstra and Barry Dorrans (Twitter <link><linkText>@blowdart</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Please leave feedback about what you liked and what you would like to see improved, not only about the tutorial itself but also about the products that it demonstrates.
trans-unit.target: Please leave feedback about what you liked and what you would like to see improved, not only about the tutorial itself but also about the products that it demonstrates.

trans-unit.source: Your feedback will help us prioritize improvements.
trans-unit.target: Your feedback will help us prioritize improvements.

trans-unit.source: You can also request and vote on new topics at <link><linkText>Show Me How With Code</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also request and vote on new topics at <link><linkText>Show Me How With Code</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.target: test
